events.name: Installing Intel HAXM, Data Abstract for Android and Beyond the Phone and Tablet
events.description:
For the Android developer, we all know that testing the app is part of the tasks. Sometime, we load the app to the actual devices and on the other time, we use emulator on the computer.

The Intel Hardware Accelerated Execution Manager (Intel® HAXM) is a hardware-assisted virtualization engine (hypervisor) that uses Intel Virtualization Technology (Intel® VT) to speed up Android app emulation on a host machine. We will learn how to install HAXM from Intel. Please see the Special Note below for information on Installation Guide & System Requirements.

Along with Android line, you may be asked to extend your Android app to the large databases such as Oracle Databases, Microsoft SQL Server, Oracle MySQL, PostgreSQL, Microsoft SQL Azure ... etc., Jim McKeeth will show us a framework that can help you to achieve this task. For more information,

http://www.remobjects.com/da/

 

It is the holiday seasons, and you probably have checked out or thinking about a few new devices recently, Jim McKeeth wants to show us where Android has landed beyond the smartphones, tablets and Google TV devices. Seeing is believing, Jim will bring a couple of devices with him, so do not miss this opportunities! For more information about

Wimm,

https://my.wimm.com/developer

Moverio,

http://www.epson.com/cgi-bin/Store/jsp/Moverio/Home.do#tabs=1

Ouya,

http://www.ouya.tv/devs/

 

 

Special Notes:

1. Installation Guide & System Requirements for Windows, Mac OS X, and Linux Ubuntu (64-bit):

http://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/intel-hardware-accelerated-execution-manager

2. Coming to 2013, there could likely to be changes that affect the operations of GDG East Bay. If you are interested to help or want to understand what these changes would be, please come to the 5:40pm, Special friends of GDG East Bay 2013 meeting.

3. GDG East Bay appreciates the support from the city of Dublin, California. Regional Meeting Room and Dublin library Community Room are both first-class locations for business and social events.

4. We are close to the first anniversary of "relaunch" of GDG East Bay, and our speaker, Jim McKeeth is the 600th member of GDG East Bay. Let's celebrate during the two events in December 2012.

 

Agenda:

5:40pm Special friends of GDG East Bay 2013 meeting

6:00pm Check in, networking and pizza/food (thank you, RemObjects Software)

6:15pm Installing Intel HAXM (Hardware Accelerated Execution Manager) (Anuj Goyal, Intel Corporation)

7:15pm Transition break between two sessions

7:25pm Data Abstract for Android (Jim McKeeth, RemObjects Software)

8:00pm Beyond the Phone and Tablet (Jim McKeeth, RemObjects Software)

8:35pm Raffle. Clean up. Networking

 

Session's Description:

Installing Intel HAXM (Hardware Accelerated Execution Manager) (Anuj Goyal, Intel Corporation)

Intel will help developers install HAXM.

 

Data Abstract for Android (Jim McKeeth, RemObjects Software) Using Data Abstract to connect Android apps to large back end databases like Oracle Database, Microsoft SQL Server ... etc.

 

Beyond the Phone and Tablet (Jim McKeeth, RemObjects Software)

Android is running on some cool and creative platforms. What is involved in developing on these platforms? Devices include Wimm, Moverio & Ouya.

 

Speaker's Bio:

Anuj Goyal is currently with Accelerated Leadership Program (ALP) at the Intel Corporation. Previously, Anuj was with Coverity Inc. and Siebel Systems after graduated from University of Michigan.

 

Jim McKeeth is a veteran software developer, community activist, podcaster, blogger and conference presenter with 20 years of experience. He is developer evangelist for RemObjects Software where he travels the globe teaching and inspiring developers to achieve new levels of success in their development efforts. Jim’s belief that training should be fun and informative is evident by his creative style. Jim presents at conferences all across North America and Europe. In addition to traditional conference sessions, he also trains full-day and multi-day workshops

events.name: Creating 2nd screen exp & app on LG Smart TV
events.description:
We are holding this meeting a week ahead (on the second Monday instead of the third Monday). We are celebrating the 4th quarterly Industry Innovation event at the GDG East Bay and the Moving Visually is the theme.

 

Special notes:

1. As of December 3rd, I received notices that the "Open Source Automotive Platforms" session will be postponded until early 2013, and I am looking for a presenter for a new sesssion. I will remove those contents away from this web site soon.

2. GDG East Bay collects $3.00 cash to cover meeting expense, please bring exact change to the meeting. Thank you.

 

Visually speaking, Kemal Altintas of LG Electronics will show us how to participate the upcoming TV App world. Imagine, your app will not just run on 3"-5" smartphones' screens, on 7-10" tablets' screens, on 11"-30+" computers' screens, but on 30"-60+" TVs' screens.

 

Imagine, you and your friends competing on a TV App using connected devices of your choices.

 

Come to GDG East Bay, and learn how you can make the favorite TV program to be the one that runs your App.

 

Tenatively, this is the day that we put our membership share power to work, we may have to organize an earlier time where we meet to get the materials to be shared to the organizations which can use them. We will share some video clips or pictures with the members in this meeting.

 

Session's Description:

Creating 2nd screen experience and TV app on LG Smart TV (Kemal Altintas, LG Electronics)

There are many 2nd screen app available in both Android and Apple devices.  Some focuses on content discovery, some focuses on social aspects, and more.  Kemal will go over how you as an Android developer can create 2nd screen app that works with LG Smart TV.  He will also cover how you can create TV applications that interact with actual TV content.

 

Speakers' Bio:

Kemal Altintas is an expert business development and product management professional focusing on Connected Consumer Electronics, Digital Media and Pay TV space. Currently, he is a part of LG Electronics Innovation Development Team in Silicon Valley. He has spearheaded LG Smart TV's second screen efforts on Android and iOS platforms. He has led projects with mobile app developers and content partners to integrate 2nd screen experiences into LG products. He worked with many large and small companies to introduce social TV experiences to the market. He also worked on content discovery and recommendation engines, cloud based solutions, 3D and 4K content services. Prior to LG, he spent time at DivX and Tivo, working with global pay TV operators and set top box manufacturers. He spent considerable time in Europe talking to operators and device manufacturers and still enjoys jumping on the plane and going there. He holds BS and MS degrees in Computer Science. He received his MBA from UC San Diego with a focus on Technology Marketing.

events.name: Introduction to Mono for Android
events.description:
Welcome to GDG East Bay meeting page. We typically meet on the first Monday monthly, and there is a special quarterly Industry Innovation session on the 3rd Monday of the third month at each quarter. For the first half of 2013, we will meet at the Dublin library Community Room.

Happy New Year, members of the GDG East Bay. Many of the members request for video taping of our events and/or video streaming. Can we figure out how to make it happen?

First of all, I want to thank the city of Dublin, City of Pleasanton, GWC (USA) and 580Exec for providing places for our 2012 meetings. Thank you for your support during 2012.

Secondly, I want to thank all the sponsors and the speakers. We learned a lot from you and there were many great exchange among the members and the speakers. Thank you for keeping us at the leading edge of the technology. We hope to see many of you in 2013.

I want to appreciate all the members of GDG East Bay, we went through the name change from East Bay GTUG around middle of 2012. Thank you for all the support, help and encouragements. We will try some new approaches and adjustments in 2013, for no other reasons, but to make GDG East Bay a great place for you to learn and exchange knowledge and ideas.

We are taking nominations of speakers and sponsors. Please e-mail me for your suggestions. Thank you very much!

GDG East Bay appreciates the support from the city of Dublin, California. Regional Meeting Room and Dublin library Community Room are both first-class locations for business and social events.

GDG East Bay appreciates the superb support from Google Inc.

 

During 2013, we will examine various ways to create Android Apps. Craig Dunn from Xamarin will lead us to see how one can use C# programming language.

 

After the Mono for Android session, we will hold a raffle before moving to the planning meeting for 2013 events. This is your chance to help formulate programs for the GDG East Bay.

 

Agenda:

6:00pm Check in, networking, food/drink (thank you, Xamarin)

6:15pm Introduction to Mono for Android (Craig Dunn, Xamarin)

7:25pm Raffle.

7:40pm 2013 events Planning meeting

8:15pm Clean up. Networking 

 

Session's Description:

Introduction to Mono for Android (Craig Dunn, Xamarin)

Xamarin's Mono for Android tools let you build applications for Android using C#. You can write code on a Mac with MonoDevelop, or for Windows choose between MonoDevelop and Visual Studio. What's in it for Java developers? C# is an easy leap, and you can then re-use your code on iOS and Windows devices. We'll look at the tooling, building an Android app with C# and the principles of sharing code with iPhones, iPads and Windows."

 

Speakers' Bio:

Craig Dunn is the Developer Evangelist for Xamarin. Craig's been working with MonoTouch and Mono for Android since their initial betas back in 2009, being primarily a C# developer prior to that (although with a range of experience from Smalltalk & Perl to Java & VBScript). Craig has previously worked on commercial iOS and Android projects using Objective-C, Java and C# before starting work at Xamarin in 2011. He currently writes code & user-documentation and is working feverishly on the upcoming Evolve conference - being held in April in Austin, Texas. You can reach Craig by:

http://conceptdev.blogspot.com

@conceptdev

events.name: Heads Up: AT&T Mobile App Hackathon - GAME JAM!
events.description:
Important Notice: Heads Up events listed at the Google Developer Group (GDG) East Bay are selected events that some members may be interested.

The following information mainly came from the event registration page. If you want to attend this event, please register by 5PM, Friday, January 25th 2013:
http://mobileapppa4-eorg.eventbrite.com/

Please note that the official event is titled, "AT&T Mobile App Hackathon - Palo Alto - GAME JAM!", but the event is not held at the AT&T Foundry office at Palo Alto this time. This weekend hackathon is held at the Nest GSV office at Redwood City. For this Heads Up event post, I dropped the "- Palo Alto" words to avoid confusion.

*** Event information begins ***

Are you Interested in building mobile games?

Mobile App Hackathon is an event produced by the AT&T Developer Program that is designed for attendees (technical & non-technical) to build apps/mobile apps, get fed, compete for prizes across different categories and most importantly: meet new people and scout for teammates to work on new or current projects. Our hackathon will introduce you to the latest cutting edge tools to help deploy your own app with a website backend, fully hosted in the cloud.
This specific hackathon will feature speakers from the gaming industry as well as mentors that can help you with the game you have been thinking about building or advance the game you have already built.
To make this event even more interesting for you, Wild Tangent has graciously offered to FINISH the first place game, free of charge. You own the rights to the game and Wild Tangent / AT&T will help get the word out through our channels.

We Supply: Quick presentations and code samples that help to bootstrap your hacking, food to keep you going, and caffeine to keep you awake. Along with technical senseis to assist you in building faster, smarter, and with new tools.
You Bring: Your laptop, skills & ideas. Come with a collaborative, team focused mindset and/or team up in advance on

Twitter/Facebook/Google+ via the #atthack hashtag.

Whether you are a backend person and code in Ruby/PHP/.NET or are a designer and only work with Illustrator, you are invited to attend this event. Every group needs a good balance of talent and your development skills are needed!

Weekend event agenda:

Friday, 1/24/2013:

6PM: Kickoff event with drinks, networking, and developer dating which leads into idea pitches and team formation.
7PM: Speakers present (see below under "Speakers:")
8PM: Pitch ideas and form teams

Saturday, 1/25/2013:
10AM: The fun continues with an all day hackathon. Work with the teams that you formed on Friday night to produce the app spec’d out the night before. Senseis will be available throughout the entire event to help you code up your solution. App submissions will be accepted throughout the day with a deadline of 7PM.
7PM: Promptly at 7PM, teams will begin pitching their ventures. Pitches are limited to three (3) minutes per team.

Prizes:

The following prizes are experiential and geared towards accelerating you towards a successful business as well as expanding your network and industry knowledge:

Best Hackathon Overall Mobile Gaming App
1st Place - $500 in Gift Cards for the team
2nd Place - $300 in Gift Cards for the team
3rd Place - $200 in Gift Cards for the team

Greatest Market Potential
A 3-month incubation period at nestGSV including:

Alex Donn, Senior Marketing Manager at AT&T, is based out of sunny Seattle! His passion is educating developers young and old about mobile application development best practices through events like hackathons that fuse the collective interests of multiple technology and business leaders. He loves bacon and is allergic to all types of gluten.

events.name: Special HTC event on the "Bluetooth Low Energy" and a mini-hackathon
events.description:
Welcome to GDG East Bay meeting page. We typically meet on the first Monday monthly, and there is a special quarterly Industry Innovation session on the 3rd Monday of the third month at each quarter.

We are excited to have a special presentation from HTC. Lance Nanek will show us some exciting green energy technology called "Bluetooth Low Energy", this is a new addition to the Bluetooth Core Specification introduced by the Bluetooth 4.0. For details,

http://www.htc.com/us/smartphones/htc-evo-4g-lte/

See the revolutionary new products coming out using Bluetooth Low Energy and take a crack at writing your own code for it. The Cookoo watch, successful on Kickstarter and being sold now at AT&T, brings all your phone's status right to your wrist and adds a handy command button for talking back. The Polar H7 Heart Rate Senser lasts a year on a coin cell battery with no recharging. Join the revolutionary internet of things using new low energy technology.

A technical presentation will be followed by a coding workshop (aka mini-hackathon) where the best attempt to connect to a BLE device will win an Evo 4G LTE smartphone. Use this opportunity to learn about a new technology and work on your own code and coding skills with expert assistance.

If you are interested to participate in the coding workshop, please follow the comments posted by Lance in the conversations session below to ensure you have the required Android SDK version and HTC BLE SDK add-on.

 

Note: GDG East Bay collects $3.00 cash to cover meeting expense, please bring exact change to the meeting. Thank you.

We are taking nominations of speakers and sponsors. Please e-mail me for your suggestions. Thank you very much!

GDG East Bay appreciates the support from the city of Dublin, California. Regional Meeting Room and Dublin library Community Room are both first-class locations for business and social events.

GDG East Bay appreciates the superb support from Google Inc.

 

Agenda:

6:00pm Check in, networking, food/drink (thank you,HTC)

6:15pm Bluetooth Low Energy (Lance Nanek, HTC)

7:25pm Break

7:30pm Mini-hackathon coding session using the BLE

8:45pm Raffle. Clean up. Networking

 

Session's Description:

Bluetooth Low Energy (Lance Nanek, HTC)

Bluetooth Low Energy is here and enabling the internet of things. Phones, wearable sensors, and other devices can read and write data to each other for over a year using only the power of a single coin cell battery. Come see what cool new Bluetooth Low Energy device is shipping in a major carrier store, what hackers came up with at the AT&T Developer Summit, and learn about how to write code for HTC's BLE capable phones to talk to all the latest devices.

 

Speakers' Bio:

Lance Nanek is a Developer Evangelist at HTC. He has ten years of experience in information technology: implementing web metrics for ibm.com at IBM, writing Java web applications at State University of New York System Administration, and working on Android apps for many companies, including CardioTrainer by WorkSmart Labs with over three million downloads. He has a master's degree in Computer Science from State University of New York University at Albany.

events.name: Spring forward to the Open Source Automotive Platforms and Big Data on the Cloud
events.description:
Welcome to GDG East Bay meeting page. We typically meet on the first Monday monthly, and there is a special quarterly Industry Innovation session on the 3rd Monday of the third month at each quarter.

We are delight to see you in our upcoming meetings. Please feel free to invite your friends and co-workers to learn and share your expertise.

We are taking nominations of speakers and sponsors. Please e-mail me for your suggestions. Thank you very much!

GDG East Bay

GDG East Bay appreciates the superb support from Google Inc.appreciates the support from the city of Dublin, California. Regional Meeting Room and Dublin library Community Room are both first-class locations for business and social events.

Vroom, vroom... that is the sound of gas-powered automobile. GDG East Bay is very happy to have TJ Giuli of Ford introducing the OpenXC, which is a research software/hardware platform that exposes internal vehicle data through an Android service to us.

 

TJ recommended to move this event from our December 2012 meeting to March 2013. Here is a URL on a report about the OpenXC On January 8th 2013 at International Consumer Electronics Show (CES):

http://techcrunch.com/2013/01/08/ford-launches-its-openxc-sdk-and-hardware-specs-to-let-developers-access-its-cars-sensors-and-metrics/

More information about OpenXC can be found:

http://openxcplatform.com/overview/index.html

TJ will bring a Ford automobile to show us how the technology works.

After the break, Gurumurthy Yeleswarapu of swatcloud will give us a very detailed coverage of Big Data, Cloud and Mobile via user cases.

 

Note:

GDG East Bay will collect $3.00, exact change preferred, to cover meeting expenses.

 

Agenda:

6:00pm Check in, networking, and food

6:15pm Open Source Automotive Platforms (TJ Giuli, Ford)

7:25pm Break between two sessions

7:30pm IT : Big Data , Cloud and Mobile (Gurumurthy Yeleswarapu, swatcloud)

8:45pm Raffle. Clean up. Networking

 

Sessions' Description:

Open Source Automotive Platforms (TJ Giuli, Ford)

OpenXC is a research software/hardware platform that exposes internal vehicle data through an Android service, allowing apps to augment the kinds of experiences they can provide both in the vehicle as well as outside the vehicle.  I will give technical details on how OpenXC works, some prototype apps Ford has been experimenting with, and talk about how experimenters can get involved.

 

 

IT: Big D

ata , Cloud and Mobile (Gurumurthy Yeleswarapu, swatcloud) For us in the San Francisco Bay area, there is not an hour pass that these words do not come to our attention: Big Data, Cloud and Mobile. Let Gurumurthy give us a comprehensive coverage of these exciting areas via presentation and live demo of how to integrated them.

 

Speakers' Bios:

TJ Giuli leads Ford’s newly-established Silicon Valley Lab in downtown Palo Alto.  His research interests lie in mobile computing and secure, privacy-preserving vehicular software architectures. His recent work involves architecting research software platforms to enable third-party software development on cars.  TJ has had the pleasure of working with many gifted students while teaching classes at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor on automotive software design, and led the technical effort for the American Journey 2.0 project (http://makezine.com/americanjourney2.0/).  He received his Ph.D. in computer science from Stanford University in 2005.

 

Gurumurthy Yeleswarapu is a 20-year veteran in the high tech sector. He founded a couple of companies (Electronics Inc. and e-Colt Systems Inc) before SwatCloud. He worked as technologist and business development roles over past several years! Networking, Security, Cloud are areas of Gurumurthy's interest. He got couple of patents.

events.name: DevFest Silicon Valley
events.description:
Welcome to GDG East Bay meeting page. We typically meet on the first Monday monthly, and there is a special quarterly Industry Innovation session on the 3rd Monday of the third month at each quarter. Occasionally, GDG East Bay hosts special events, such as DevFest Silicon Valley.

 

*** Start of important notice ***

There is a fee to attend this DevFest. To register for this event, you must use the following URL:

http://devfestsiliconvalley.eventbrite.com/

Note: As of 3/12/2013, the event is full, if you want to, you can add your name to the waitlist.

*** End of important notice ***

 

We are delight to see you in our upcoming meetings. Please feel free to invite your friends and co-workers to learn and share your expertise.

We are taking nominations of speakers and sponsors. Please e-mail me for your suggestions. Thank you very much!

GDG East Bay appreciates the superb support from Google Inc.

In October 2012, GDG East Bay organized its first DevFest at the San Jose Convention Center. Now GDG East Bay is proud to host the upcoming DevFest Silicon Valley with GDG Silicon Valley, GDG San Francisco and Estelle Weyl at the Google's Crittenden campus in Mountain View, California.

DevFest is a series of community-led events that have technical sessions centered around Google developer technologies and platforms such as Android, Chrome, Google+, and App Engine. This DevFest will have a particular focus on women-inclusion and bringing the female developer community together to teach, learn, code and network.

Given the above focus, this DevFest is not a women-only event, as is instead an opportunity to encourage diversity within the developer community through female speakers and participants. Both men and women are welcome!

The following information is based on the information as of 3/13/2013, from the event registration URL,

http://devfestsiliconvalley.eventbrite.com/

After you register, you can checkout the transportation survey form (mainly for attendees living in San Francisco). (Note: as of 3/13/3013, the shuttle from/to San Francisco is full.)

 

Agenda:

9:15am -   9:45am Registration

9:45am - 10:00am Welcome

10:00am-12:15pm Sessions

12:15pm - 1:15pm Lunch

1:15pm -   2:45pm Sessions

2:45pm -   3:00pm Break

3:00pm -   4:30pm Sessions

4:30pm -   4:45pm Break

4:45pm -   5:45pm Lightning Talks

5:45pm -   8:00pm Dinner and party

Sessions' Description:

Feature Detection in the Real World (Pamela Fox)

In an ideal world, we would always use feature detection to decide what features to serve our users. Unfortunately, in the real world, there are practical problems with that approach: some features are undetectable, some tests take too long, and sometimes, its just not worth the time to do them. In this talk, I'll introduce the ideas and tools behind feature detection and then discuss where we've tried to use it at Coursera and where we failed.

Beautiful Android on a Shoestring (Chiu-Ki Chan)

Want to make your app beautiful, but cannot afford a designer? Fear not, there are many easy ways to prettify your app.

The first part of the talk covers Android techniques. Learn how to use XML and Java to touch up your app with gradients and round corners, tiling backgrounds, custom fonts and much more.

The second part showcases various free and open source resources such as color schemes, graphics, patterns, fonts and icons. You can use them in your apps as well as web sites, flyers, posters, anywhere you need beautiful things.

By the end of the session you will be equipped to prettify your app and make it stand out in the crowded marketplace.

 

Mobile Approaches with HTML5 (Tomomi Imura)

Building a mobile web no longer means dumbing down an existing desktop website. With ever-evolving HTML5 and smartphone capabilities, now you can create amazing web apps running on mobile browsers. In my talk, I will cover the adaptive and responsive design approach to support multiple form-factors from desktop to mobile phones, also the mobile-specific approach with HTML5 APIs, including device APIs that make communication between a browser and hardware possible, and enable web to have "native" like experiences


10 things you didn't know a browser could do (Estelle Weyl)

It may feel like the HTML5, CSS3 and ECMAScript specifications are moving along at a snails pace, but browser capabilities are moving quickly, and it is difficult to keep up with all the new feature support. In this session we'll cover some brand spanking new and older but unknown features that make debugging, designing and developing more fun.

Automate ALL THE THINGS! (Kitt Hodsden)

From zen coding to automating commands, from code generation and browser bookmarks through webhooks to text notifications, you can make life much easier by automating parts of your web work, removing tedious, repetitive tasks and creating shortcuts so that you have more time for the interesting stuff. Let's review current techinques you need to automate all the things.

NFC Tricks and Traps (Christie English)

NFC (near field communication) is a wireless technology enabling the transfer of data such as text or numbers between two NFC enabled devices such as NFC tags and NFC enabled cell phones. In this technical presentation about developing NFC applications on the Android / PhoneGap platform, we will go into the things to be aware of about NFC tags and how to support features on non-NFC and non-Android phones.

Gay marriage: the database engineering perspective (Liz Howard)

Essentially, large databases with referential integrity aren't made to handle gay marriage. We'll look at some of the types of changes we'll have to make to the databases that run the country if we're going to become a progressive society. This talk looks at potential future changes to marriage, and how to establish relationships between humans in a truly nonbiased way. This humorous talk is great for beginners to database schemas and looks at how thinking ahead can save you time later, but can also lead to exploring unexpected areas of life.

Best Practices for Mobile Application Development on Android (Tasneem Sayeed)

This talk will provide an overview on the best practices for developing mobile applications for the Android Platform. It will provide tips for making your apps fast and more responsive including the "Golden Rules of Performance". It will cover the essentials  for an effective UX design and user experience. Furthermore, it will cover the benefits of using intents, intent receivers and handling background updates.

Introduction to Chrome Developer Tools (Dee Gill)

An introduction to developer tools, origination from webkit, documentation / resources, how to open developer tools, etc. We'll cover each of the tabs, including elements, resources, network, sources, timeline, profiles, audits, consoles as we inspect a popular website. You'll also learn how to debug JavaScript through a live demo using the inspector, breakpoints and console, and become a super user as you learn common shortcuts to navigate through this indispensable tool.

An Engineer's Guide to Learning About Your Users (Nadyne Richmond)

You've got a great idea: maybe for a new feature, or a new application, or a new website.  How can you learn whether your idea will gain traction with users?  In this 30-minute session, I'll explain how to elicit information from your users (both directly and indirectly).  I'll discuss the parallels between good code and good research, and explain how the development lifecycle applies to research too.

Google+ Sign-In (Jenny Murphy, Joanna Smith)

Google+ Sign-In is a simple, trusted way to let people sign in with their Google credentials and build even more engaging experiences across desktop and mobile.

In this presentation, Jenny Murphy and Joanna Smith guide you through the features proofed by this new feature of the Google+ Platform.

Making the YouTube Platform work for you (Amanda Surya)

From Justin Bieber to Psy, YouTube has become a platform for artists to launch themselves into international stardom. But how can developers and entrepreneurs take advantage of YouTube? In this talk, I will walk through YouTube's newly launched APIs and go through examples of businesses and cool apps built using them, so you can go built your own.

Chrome Apps: Bridge between Native and the Web (Meggin Kearney)

Today web apps require you to be online and in your browser. They have both perceived and real limitations in functionality like access to native hardware. Native apps have proven successful because of their full-fledged functionality and ease of distribution. With Chrome Apps, you can build apps that are just as powerful and integrated as the native app using web technologies. In this talk, we will take an honest look at Chrome Apps-- what it offers you now, what it could potentially offer in the near future, and how your code will run on any platform. We’ll learn how to build our own Chrome App Todo lists, walking through this code lab.

How to Test Your Javascript With Jasmine (Fiona Tay)

Learn how to get started testing your Javascript code with Jasmine, a popular testing framework. I'll explain how to set up Jasmine and write simple tests.

Google Analytics: Data for the Evolving Digital World (Andy Granowitz)

Google Analytics not only lets you measure sales and conversions, but also gives you fresh insights into how visitors use your site, how they arrived on your site, and how you can keep them coming back. In this session, you will learn how to reap full benefit from this powerful tool - from data collection to action. We will also discuss recent developments in the digital world and how analysis tools are adapting.

 

 

Speakers' Bios:

Note: We haven't finalized the line-up yet, but we have some great speakers committed to the event. Estelle Weyl, Chiu-Ki Chan, Pamela Fox, Amanda Surya, and Meggin Kearny will be covering topics like HTML5, Android and mobile programming, web performance and Google's APIs.

Pamela Fox

Pamela Fox loves to learn, teach, create, and every combination of those. During the day, she works as a frontend engineer at Coursera, working to improve the future of online education. At night and on the weekends, she teaches web development classes for the GirlDevelopIt San Francisco chapter.. Before that, she worked in Google Developer Relations, and graduated from USC's Computer Science Department (Go Trojans!).

Tomomi Imura

Tomomi (@girlie_mac) is an open web advocate, and front-end engineer with mobile focus. She has been in mobile-space since before it was cool -has been developing mobile apps, platform UI/UX and frameworks at Yahoo! Mobile, Palm, Hewlett-Packard, before the current company, Nokia, to evangelize HTML5. She also writes a technical blog athttp://girliamac.com

 

Chiu-Ki Chan

Chiu-Ki flows between both web and mobile development. At Google, she worked on the javascript frontend for Book Search, and the native Android client for Google Mobile Maps. Afterwards, she went to two different web startups, one with Django the other with Ruby on Rails, both using jquery to build interactive websites. Now she’s once again back to mobile, producing her own apps. The first title is Monkey Write, an app for learning Chinese writing.

Estelle Weyl

Estelle Weyl started her professional life in architecture and then managed teen health programs. In 2000, she took the natural step of becoming a web standardista. She has consulted for Kodakgallery, SurveyMonkey, Yahoo!, Apple, and many others. Estelle provides tutorials and detailed grids for CSS3 and HTML5 browser support in her blog. She is the author of “Mobile HTML5” (O’Reilly, July. 2013), “HTML5: The Definitive Guide” (O’Reilly, Dec. 2013) and “HTML5 and CSS3 for the Real World” (Sitepoint, 2011)

Kitt Hodsden

Kitt Hodsden is the 47th laziest person in the world, a feat which takes considerable effort. That effort has taken her to Twitter, where she and her team are building out a unified platform for the company’s supplementary websites. Before working at Twitter, Kitt co-founded CodingClan LLC, a small web development firm specializing in the rapid development and deployment of Drupal-based community and commerce websites; co-founded Hacker Dojo, a community space for hackers, tinkerers, makers and programmers in Mountain View, California; worked on Shrek and Antz; and built enough websites to lose count. When not organizing a conference or study group, preaching the gospel of lazy productivity or building another website, she can be found playing ultimate, rain or shine.

Christie English

Christie is a software developer with 10+ years of experience in the industry. Developing software for her is fun because it is a way to express creativity.  Technology is constantly changing so she enjoys keeping pace as the software engineering field evolves and putting new technology to use for people with creative solutions.  Christie believes that with change comes new opportunities.  Currently she is the founder of a startup creating pioneering NFC software.

Liz Howard

Liz Howard (@lizthedeveloper) teaches for Girl Develop It, and is currently doing a Hacker-In-Residence program at Hackbright Academy. She loves to explain engineering to people who are excited about it. Her current project is changing the gender ratio in technology.

Tasneem Sayeed

Tasneem is Mobile-savvy, Web 2.0, Social Gaming and Social Networking experienced technologist with more than a decade of software development and technical leadership experience. Tasneem is currently Principal Mobile SW Engineer at Intuit within the CTO Dev Mobile Team. Prior to Intuit, Tasneem was a Game Client Architect at Gameview Studios (subsidiary of DeNA), where she helped to optimize their top mobile social games. She has worked in early stage Web 2.0 startups such as Hiplogic (acquired by Zynga) and Bling Software. She also helped to define, implement and deploy Gemini Mobile's eXplo Social Networking Platform with Softbank Mobile (Japan) and Nokia's SNAP Mobile Networking Gaming Platform with SmarTone HK. She spent 10 years at Sun Microsystems as a Technical Lead for Java ME platform and helped to bring the first Billion Java ME handsets to market globally.

 

Dee Gill

Dee is a finance nerd / excel ninja turning programming nerd. In finance land forecasting revenue, she's been building up budgets and putting together investor / board presentations. Dee has been working at Nadyne Richmond for the last year and a half, and has recently joined their dev team. This spring she'll be in the third ever batch of women learning the art of programming at Hackbright Academy.

Nadyne Richmond

Nadyne Richmond is a Staff User Researcher at VMware, directing user experience efforts across VMware's product suite.  She created and led VMware's first internal user experience conference.  Nadyne has also worked as a researcher at Microsoft and IBM.  At Microsoft, Nadyne architected the user experience for Outlook:Mac 2011, which won a PC Magazine "Best of" award for 2010, as well as OneNote for iPad and OneNote for iPhone.

 

Jenny Murphy

Jenny is a Developer Programs Engineer working on Google Glass. Before joining Google, she worked in a wide variety of software engineering roles -- from robots at NASA to the architect of a social media startup. She is passionate about writing and education, especially on the subjects of technology and science.

 

Joanna Smith

Joanna is a Developer Programs Engineer working on Google+. Before joining Google she studied at The University of Texas at Austin, focusing on CS Education, Distributed Systems, and Natural Language Processing. She is passionate about words and education, especially with regard to technology.

Amanda Surya

Amanda leads the YouTube and Commerce Developer Relations teams where she helps partners and developers large and small to integrate with the APIs. During her spare time, she loves to encourage more women to get into tech. She helped start the Women Techmaker series, an effort to tell the stories of many successful technical women.

 

Meggin Kearney

Meggin is a technical writer for Google Chrome working on the Chrome Apps project. She’s passionate about making technology easy to understand so that developers can get started quickly-- ‘Writing less is more’. Meggin didn’t start out in technology but her curiosity drew her to it. She loves to find technical solutions to problems, even if it means pushing the boundaries on what she’s technically capable of doing. She relates to women coders whose path isn’t always the straight and narrow. She believes the skills required to steer the windy roads are key to pushing women into the forefront of technology.

 

Fiona Tay

Fiona Tay is a developer at Pivotal Labs, where she writes tests before code. She got a late start with programming, but now loves learning new languages.

 

 

 

Andy Granowitz

Andy Granowitz is an analyst at Google Analytics (GA), working to bring data-driven decision-making to Fortune 100 companies. Andy also plays a leading role in Google's customer analytics efforts, drawing on his prior work with the Wharton Customer Analytics Initiative. Andy graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with degrees in Mathematics and Statistics.

events.name: Heads Up: "SuperHappyDevHouse 53" and "Hadoop Hackathon : learn MapReduce"
events.description:
Important Notice: Heads Up events listed at the Google Developer Group (GDG) East Bay are selected events that some members may be interested.

 

The following information came from various sections of the event URLs:
http://superhappydevhouse.org/w/page/63764306/SuperHappyDevHouse53

http://www.meetup.com/BigDataGurus/events/107872562/

**************************************************

SuperHappyDevHouse is running its 53th event at the new Hacker Dojo community center. You can check them out today. The attendees can take the initiative to witness other attendees' projects, inquire the technology used, and share experience and knowledge. Projects can be software only or hardware and software combination.

 

During the evening, there is a lightning talks, for schedule and how to be on the list of lightning talks presenters,

http://superhappydevhouse.org/w/page/63835317/SHDH%2053%20Lightning%20Talks

Each SuperHappyDevHouse is different than the other. Would you like to make this event yours?

There seems to be no special registration for this event.

**************************************************

Hadoop Hackathon : learn MapReduce is a special event organized by the Big Data Gurus meetup group running during the SuperHappyDevHouse 53. For details and registration:

http://www.meetup.com/BigDataGurus/events/107872562/

This is a follow up event of the Hadoop Hackathon, see "Hackathon set for Jan 20 !" at

http://www.meetup.com/BigDataGurus/events/98701012/

 

The organizer provided the following preparation guide for the attendees:

Come Ready with:
- come with a WORKING hadoop environment.  Your choices are
1) install hadoop on your laptop
2) download a virtual machine (VM) from Cloudera / HortonWorks / WanDisco

3) or setup a hadoop cluster on EC2 for the duration of class

- if you need help setting up Hadoop, please ping me before the hackathon;  we will try to help you out

- Be comfortable programming in Java.  Have your Java development environment ready.  Either eclipse, or your favorite editor.

- come ready to learn and help others and have fun!

Notes:

1. Should you want to use the virtual machine (as in "2)" above), please download them first. A VM image can be larger than 1GB. Download the matching VM software (VMware, Oracle VM VirtualBox ...). I hope these links are the suitable ones for you to download:

a. Cloudera's Distribution Including Apache Hadoop (CDH)

https://ccp.cloudera.com/display/SUPPORT/CDH+Downloads#CDHDownloads-CDH4PackagesandDownloads

b. Hortonworks Sandbox

http://hortonworks.com/products/hortonworks-sandbox/

c. VMWare Player

https://my.vmware.com/web/vmware/free#desktop_end_user_computing/vmware_player/5_0

d. Oracle VM VirtualBox

http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/server-storage/virtualbox/downloads/index.html

2. A quick reference of MapReduce and Hadoop

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MapReduce

http://hadoop.apache.org/

events.name: Getting Started with Hadoop
events.description:
Welcome to GDG East Bay meeting page. We typically meet on the first Monday monthly, and there is a special quarterly Industry Innovation session on the 3rd Monday of the third month at each quarter.

March 25th will be the first quarterly Industry Innovation session for 2013 as we start the second year of hosting these special sessions. During 2012, we ventured into Healthcare, Space station, APIs, and smart TVs. Where will we explore in 2013? GDG East Bay is delight to see you in our meetings. Please feel free to invite your friends and co-workers to learn and share your expertise.

We are taking nominations of speakers and sponsors. Please e-mail me for your suggestions. Thank you very much!

GDG East Bay appreciates the support from the city of Dublin, California. Regional Meeting Room and Dublin library Community Room are both first-class locations for business and social events.

GDG East Bay appreciates the superb support from Google Inc.

Earlier this month, we heard from Gurumurthy about use case of Big Data. Now we are peeling another layer of the big data onion to learn the basic of Hadoop from Sujee Maniyam.

 

Note:

GDG East Bay will collect $3.00, exact change preferred, to cover meeting expenses.

 

Agenda:

6:00pm Check in, networking, and food

6:15pm Getting Started with Hadoop (Sujee Maniyam)

7:25pm Break between two sessions

7:30pm Members sessions

8:45pm Raffle. Clean up. Networking

 

Session's Description:

Getting Started with Hadoop (Sujee Maniyam)

Hadoop and Big Data is the all the rage these days.  So how does one go about learning Hadoop?  First step is to install hadoop on a
workstation or laptop.  This session discusses options on getting
Hadoop dev environment setup.  We will talk about distributions,
install choices and dos and don'ts.

The intended audience : developers who want to setup hadoop and learn hadoop.

Speakers' Bios:

Sujee Maniyam is an experienced/hands-on BigData architect. He has been developing software for the past 12 years in a variety of
technologies (enterprise, web and mobile). He currently focuses on
Hadoop, BigData, NOSQL and Amazon Cloud Services. His clients include early stage startups in online advertising and enterprise companies like Hitachi Data Systems.

Sujee stays active in Hadoop / Open Source community. He runs a
developer focused meetup and Hadoop hackathons called 'Big Data
 Gurus'. He has presented at variety of meetups.

Sujee contributes to Hadoop project and his open source projects can be found on GitHub. He writes about Hadoop and other technologies on his website.

He is a co-author of free hadoop book available online at
http://hadoopilluminated.com/book.php

Connect with Sujee in Linkedin at:

http://www.linkedin.com/in/sujeemaniyam

events.name: Heads Up: Udacity Study Group for HTML5 Game Programming Course (CS255)-SFHTML5
events.description:
Important Notice: Heads Up events listed at the Google Developer Group (GDG) East Bay are selected events that some members may be interested.

The following information came from various sections of the event URL:
http://www.sfhtml5.org/events/105236002/?eventId=105236002

To apply for this study group:
http://goo.gl/eThVW

SF HTML5 meetup group is hosting an 8-week study group for the new Udacity HTML5 Game Programming course (CS255). For more information, see the recording of the recent Google Developers Live session. In these study groups, course instructors Colt McAnlis, Peter Lubbers, and Sean Bennett will be on hand to answer your questions. This is also great if you're participating in the Games contest (great prizes!) that is running in parallel.

Spots are limited. It is expected that you're enrolled in the course and are completing a unit every week so you can ask questions about the materials covered. It goes without saying that you're expected to actually show up if you register. The study group is offered for free, but space is very limited and if you're registered but don't show up, you're preventing someone else from coming.

The study group consists of 8 consecutive weekly meetings from 6:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. PST. Here is the schedule:

(Note: Only the first session is on Wednesday, the other 7 sessions are on Mondays)

Wednesday, February 20—Units 0 and 1
Monday, February 25 Unit 2
Monday, March 4th—Unit 3
Monday, March 11th—Unit 4
Monday, March 18th—Unit 5
Monday, March 25th—Unit 6
Monday, April 1st (no joke!)—Unit 7
Monday, April 8th—Deployment, Wrapup

SF HTML5 meetup group informs who can be enrolled by February 19, 2013 if you have a spot. If you can't physically attend, there will be live-streaming the study group and will have a way for you to submit questions remotely. Please check the comment section of

http://www.sfhtml5.org/events/105236002/?eventId=105236002

with the location and the moderator URL.

Special Notes:

https://www.udacity.com/wiki/CS255/Notes

According to the CDC, one in every 88 children has been identified with an Autsim Spectrum Disorder. For this event, produced by the AT&T Developer Program, we have teamed up with Autism Speaks to bring you autism app projects specifically requested and voted on by the autism community. To help you along the way, we’ll have not only technical experts, but also experts on and members of the autism community to answer your questions and provide feedback on your applications.

Agenda:

6PM - Kickoff event with dinner, networking, and developer dating which leads into idea pitches and team formation.

events.name: Heads Up: Hertz Mobility & Connected Vehicle Hackathon 2013
events.description:
Important Notice: Heads Up events listed at the Google Developer Group (GDG) East Bay are selected events that some members may be interested.

 

The following information came from various sections of the event URL, and you must register there if you want to attend:
http://hertzhackathonsv.eventbrite.com/

 

Join Hertz Corporation in building a more connected traveler experience!

Hertz Corporation is hosting a hackathon dedicated to building the next big thing in Mobility and the Connected Vehicle for business and leisure travel!

The organizers are looking for people to build mobile apps and hacks for a more connected traveler experience. Whether you are on a business trip or traveling for leisure, there are a million details to keep track of based on your precise location and your agenda. The focus of this hackathon is on using the Hertz rental car as a console for integrating your schedule, responsibilities and physical location into one seamless experience. Come show us what your version of a more perfect vacation or business trip looks like!

Participation in this hackathon will be rewarded with over $50k in prizes and the eyes of leaders in the connected car, mobility and transportation space - including Hertz Corporation, <a>AT&T</a>, Nokia HERE, EasilyDo, Twilio, Kiva and others!


Agenda:

Friday, April 19th 2013:

5pm - Kickoff event with drinks, networking, and developer dating. which leads into idea pitches and team formation.

6pm - Dinner

7pm- Opening speeches and presentations from Hertz Corporation CIO, Joe Eckroth; Rob Moore, Hertz Vice President of Global Information Technology; and our sponsors Nokia, HERE, AT&T, EasilyDo, Twilio and Kiva. Our sponsors will present their APIs and challenges.

9pm - Have an app idea? Each participant who signed up to pitch gets 3 minutes to present their idea. Open networking and team formation follows. Please enter your projects here on HackerLeague.

Saturday, , April 20th 2013:

5pm - Presentations start promptly at 5. Each team will have 3 minutes to pitch their hack to our judges.

7pm - Judging followed by prize-giving.

8pm - Closing words from the organizers.

Prizes:

Hertz - Over $50k in cash prizes

AT&T - $500 in cash prizes

</a>Nokia (HERE)<a href="http://www.eventbrite.com/%20developer.here.com" target="_blank"> - 3 Month Incubation at nestGSV

EasilyDo - AWS Credits

Twilio - three one-year Premium Spotify Memberships

Kiva - TBA

 

Speaker's Bios:

Joseph F. Eckroth, Executive Vice President, Global Customer Care, Corporate Program Management Office and Process Improvement, Global Revenue Management Processes and Systems and Chief Information Officer

Mr. Eckroth has served as Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer of Hertz Holdings and Hertz since June 2007 and Global Customer Care since April 2009. Mr. Eckroth also oversees the Corporate Program Management Office and Process Improvement, Global Revenue Management Processes and Systems function and Navigations Solutions business since December 2010, which is the exclusive provider of the Hertz Neverlost units and related services. Prior to joining Hertz Holdings and Hertz, Mr. Eckroth served as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer of New Century Financial Corporation from January 2006 through June 2007. He joined New Century Financial Corporation as Chief Information Officer in August 2005. Previously, Mr. Eckroth served as the Chief Information Officer for Mattel, Inc. and two of General Electric's business units, GE Medical Systems and GE Industrial Systems.

 

SENSEIS

Luv Tulsidas, Director of Web Development, Hertz Corporation

Luv is responsible for the development & support of Hertz’ e-Commerce websites.  Luv led the development and launched a centralized international Rent-a-Car (iRAC) platform for Hertz. Luv has also been responsible for the development and promotion of eCommerce solutions for emerging businesses at Hertz such as the new Hertz Rent2Buy and Hertz on Demand programs. Most recently, Luv has been focused on evangelizing HTML5 and promoting the “build once deploy everywhere” ideology.

 

Alistair Adams, Nokia Connected Car Group Product Manager

Alistair Adams is a Product Manager in Nokia’s Connected Car group. He’s been involved in the Automotive IVI industry for the last 5 years since just before Nokia acquired Trolltech, the creator of the Qt C++ application and UI framework. With Qt part of Nokia, Alistair was responsible for the widespread adoption of Qt within the automotive IVI segment and its adoption by the GENIVI alliance. Prior to Trolltech Alistair was at Fonav, a startup building WiFi handsets and at Openwave delivering browsers into handsets right at the birth of the mobile internet. Alistair holds a degree in Engineering from the University of Cambridge in the UK.

 

Joel Franusic, Twilio, Developer Evangelist

Joël Franusic is a Developer Evangelist at Twilio and Co-Organizer of SuperHappyDevHouse. He's been using GNU/Linux since Linux kernel[masked] and loves sharing his deep knowledge of the web with others. Prior to joining Twilio, Joel spent 2.5 years as a Developer Evangelist at Microsoft. When he isn't helping to plan hacker parties, he likes to spend his time thinking about how one might store data for 10,000 years.

 

Tony Mataya, Twilio, Developer Relations Manager

Tony Mataya is a Developer Relations Manager for Twilio. Prior to joining Twilio, Tony was in school at the University of Texas where he worked for a handful of startups and started a political news aggregation website that matched up left-leaning articles to right-leaning articles. Outside of work, Tony enjoys playing basketball and dabbling in complex cultural data analysis.

And others! Stay tuned.

 

JUDGES:

Joseph F. Eckroth, Hertz Corporation, Executive Vice President, Global Customer Care, Corporate Program Management Office and Process Improvement, Global Revenue Management Processes and Systems and Chief Information Officer

 

Mr. Eckroth has served as Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer of Hertz Holdings and Hertz since June 2007 and Global Customer Care since April 2009. Mr. Eckroth also oversees the Corporate Program Management Office and Process Improvement, Global Revenue Management Processes and Systems function and Navigations Solutions business since December 2010, which is the exclusive provider of the Hertz Neverlost units and related services. Prior to joining Hertz Holdings and Hertz, Mr. Eckroth served as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer of New Century Financial Corporation from January 2006 through June 2007. He joined New Century Financial Corporation as Chief Information Officer in August 2005. Previously, Mr. Eckroth served as the Chief Information Officer for Mattel, Inc. and two of General Electric's business units, GE Medical Systems and GE Industrial Systems.

 

Thilo Koslowski, Gartner Inc., VP, Distinguished Analyst, and Automotive Practice Founder

Thilo Koslowski is Vice President, Distinguished Analyst and founder of the Automotive practice at Gartner Inc., the largest business and technology strategy advisory company in the world.  Mr. Koslowski is recognized as a global thought leader, futurist and strategic advisor regarding the evolution of the automotive industry, the connected vehicle, mobility innovation and new business models.  In his role Mr. Koslowski works with senior executive business and technology leaders in the automotive, consumer electronics, Internet, communication and technology industries on disruptive and successful cross-industry business opportunities.  He is also an advisor for venture capitalists and public agencies focusing on a variety of topics including new mobility and transportation concepts, autonomous driving, e-Mobility and mobility-as-a-service. Mr. Koslowski’s work spans across the entire automotive value-chain including vehicle-centric information and communication technologies (Vehicle ICT), marketing & sales, distribution of automobiles, customer centricity and the automotive supply-chain. Before founding Gartner’s Automotive practice in Silicon Valley in 1999, Mr. Koslowski was Lead Consultant in Gartner’s Consulting Practice where he managed global consulting assignments for companies in the automotive and emerging technologies markets. Prior to that, he worked in various marketing and strategy positions for a premium German automaker.  Mr. Koslowski graduated from the Technical University (RWTH) Aachen in Germany and holds a master's degree in Business Studies with majors in Marketing, European Economy and Production Engineering.

events.description:

This is the second Alameda County Apps Challenge, following the first one held on December 8th, 2012 at Castro Valley library.

 

Alameda County Apps Challenge wants to get the attendees to learn about local government and the services that are provided and determine how you can make a difference. Then you can use technology to improve your local government. Tap into your community pride and your activist spirit, bring your ideas and your technological know-how and take the Challenge. Showcase your own ideas or collaborate with others in your community to see how quickly and accurately you can design and create a software app or concept that addresses a community need in Alameda County.

.

Join your peer designers, software developers, and innovators and participate in a day of fun, food, and technology. Using Alameda County datasets, Build, Design, Create, and Share new concepts and apps that will benefit local education and literacy, improve civic engagement, provide support for neighborhood watches / crime prevention, and help support services and activities for seniors. Submitted apps can run on the web, or on mobile devices.

events.name: Checking Out The BlackBerry Platform (Port your Android Apps + Z10 raffle)
events.description:
Welcome to GDG East Bay meeting page. We typically meet on the first Monday monthly, and there is a special quarterly Industry Innovation session on the 3rd Monday of the third month at each quarter.

Do you have something (related to the GDG) to share with other attendees? Please let us know.

We are taking nominations of speakers and sponsors. Please e-mail me for your suggestions. Thank you very much!

 

In May, we welcome Larry McDonough of BlackBerry, he will give us a very comprehensive coverage of the new BlackBerry 10 platform to us. Larry will raffle off a BlackBerry Z10.

With smart features such as Camera with Time Shift Mode, Blackberry Keyboard, BlackBerry Hub and BBM Video with Screen Share, the BlackBerry Z10 is a very smartly designed smartphone. Check out the features at:

http://us.blackberry.com/smartphones/blackberry-z10.html?LID=us:bb:devices:blackberryz10:getdetails&LPOS=us:bb:devices

 

Note: GDG East Bay collects $3.00 cash to cover meeting expense, please bring exact change to the meeting. Thank you.

GDG East Bay appreciates the support from the city of Dublin, California. Regional Meeting Room and Dublin library Community Room are both first-class locations for business and social events.

GDG East Bay appreciates the superb support from Google Inc.

 

Agenda:

6:00pm Check in, networking, and food (thank you, BlackBerry)

6:15pm Checking Out The BlackBerry Platform (Port your Android Apps + Device raffle) (Larry McDonough, BlackBerry)

7:25pm Break

7:30pm Excitement continues

8:45pm Raffle. Clean up. Networking

 

Session's Description:

Larry will begin by reviewing the platform including all runtimes.   He will take attendees' APKs and port them to BlackBerry 10 live on stage in under 60 seconds each.

NOTE:  apps that use the google NDK or proprietary google APIs won’t port.  Just straight android java apps.  However, if they don’t port, the process will highlight why.

 

Please feel free to explore the section for the developers,

https://developer.blackberry.com/

and participate in this interactive session with questions with Larry.

 

Download URLs:

1) the BlackBerry 10 Native SDK:

http://developer.blackberry.com/cascades/download/

2) BlackBerry 10 device simulators

http://developer.blackberry.com/cascades/download/bb10allsimversions/

 

May 14-16, 2013 <a>BlackBerry Jam America</a> will be held in Orlando World Center Marriott (Florida). This is the annual conference for the BlackBerry developers. Should you be interested to attend, please inquire Larry.

 

Larry also will review and demo the BlackBerry 10 platform and answer any questions about getting your apps into BlackBerry World, promoting them, etc.  I’ll also raffle off a device (PlayBook or a new Z10).  Maybe both!

 

Speaker's Bio:

Larry McDonough is the Principal Evangelist for BlackBerry.  He has spoken at numerous conferences on topics such as Mobile Monetization, Android development on BlackBerry, Mobile App Security, HTML5 vs. Native, and BlackBerry 10.  Larry is an award-winning Product Management professional with a track record of leading the design and development of successful and innovative new products. Larry has worked for numerous companies in Silicon Valley and Los Angeles including Nasa JPL, Walt Disney Studios, Silicon Graphics, and numerous startups some acquired by Apple and Google.  Prior to joining RIM, Larry managed the Java ME (J2ME) mobile platform at Sun Microsystems and also led the JavaFX Graphics & Animation and Media engineering teams through its initial release cycles. Larry has domain expertise in mobile platforms, computer graphics, animation, gaming, digital media, user experience, HTML5, and a passion for interactive, networked devices with high-res screens. Larry lives in Silicon Valley and works at of RIM's Mountain View, CA location.

You can contact Larry by,

Twitter: @Lmcdunna

LinkedIn: http://www.linkedin.com/in/lmcdunna

His BlackBerry devblogs:  http://devblog.blackberry.com/author/lmcdunna/

His Personal blog:  http://techniety.blogspot.com/

events.name: Celebrating summer with Samsung with AllShare SDK and Chord SDK, and maybe Tizen
events.description:
Welcome to GDG East Bay meeting page. We typically meet on the first Monday monthly, and there is a special quarterly Industry Innovation session on the 3rd Monday of the third month at each quarter.

Summer is almost here! Let's celebrate!

Note: GDG East Bay collects $3.00 cash to cover meeting expense, please bring exact change to the meeting. Thank you.

GDG East Bay appreciates the support from the city of Dublin, California. Regional Meeting Room and Dublin library Community Room are both first-class locations for business and social events.

GDG East Bay appreciates the superb support from Google Inc.

We are excited to have a special one-hour session with Samsung covering their latest two SDKs: AllShare Framework SDK and Samsung Chord SDK

The AllShare Framework gives you access to your content anytime, anywhere within your AllShare enabled network. The AllShare Framework SDK is a development tool that allows you to realize your ideas and create convergence applications.

By using AllShare Framework SDK, you can add following features into your applications.

- Seamlessly stream media files stored in a device or web server to other devices.

- Remotely control a Samsung Smart TV.

- Instantly mirror mobile device’s screen being displayed on another device in real-time.

The Samsung Chord (Chord) SDK allows application developers to develop local information-sharing applications without a detailed knowledge of networking.

Chord enabl

Easy discovery and connection with nearby deviceses simple real-time sharing without the cloud!

Real-time experiences between multiple devices Fast peer-to-peer connection, without the need of a server Decentralized networks where peers can come and go at any time Devices running Chord-based applications discover each other using a UDP broadcast based discovery, and then use a TCP-based protocol stack to create a reliable, peer-to-peer local communication network. This network can be used to share data, including text, binary messages and files, with selected members of the network.

More information will be available as well as possible presentation from Intel on Tizen for the second session.

 

Agenda:

6:00pm Check in, networking, and food (thank you, Samsung)

6:15pm An evening with Samsung on AllShare SDK and Chord SDK (Wei Xiao, Samsung)

7:25pm Break

7:30pm possible Tizen session (Intel)

8:45pm Raffle. Clean up. Networking

 

Session's Description:

An evening with Samsung on AllShare SDK and Chord SDK (Wei Xiao, Samsung)

AllShare Framework SDK is a development tool helps you create convergence applications. It enforces an integrated Samsung ecosystem, and provides the seamless sharing experience across Samsung devices in your meeting room and living room.

Chord SDK provides a brilliant and fun way to share content and user events in real-time between devices. The solution is perfect for use cases including Multi player games, Education etc.

In additional, Wei will give a sneak preview of the Samsung Developer Conference in SF this year.

 

Speaker's Bio:

Wei Xiaois Technical Evangelist of Samsung Developer Relations & Business Development group. Wei’s focus is to promote Samsung’s technologies and help partners integrate these exciting technologies into their products. Wei was a software engineer for more than 10 years. Prior to joining Samsung, Wei worked for Nokia, Devicecape, Motorola. Wei has a MS in Computer Science.

events.name: Wikitude and Anyline present their computer vision / augmented reality SDKs
events.description:
We humans see the world in 3D - now wikitude does, too.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=77SVP8sPYEc

Summary 

• 6:30pm - Socialize/Network

• 7:00pm - Announcements

• 7:05pm - Martin Lechner, CTO for Wikitude will introduce and discuss the Wikitude augmented reality tool set, and how it can be used with smart glasses, smartphones and tablets. 

• 7:30pm - Lukas Kinigadner , CEO Anyline will introduce and discuss the Anyline SDK enabling lightning-fast OCR 

• 8:00pm - Q&A and Demos

Session

This meetup will focus on Wikitude's and Anyline's very latest augmented reality / computer vision innovations. We will introduce you to the Wikitude SDK and Anyline SDK, its applications and features, and how you can use its power to create your very own augmented reality experiences. We are planning an interactive session, so don't expect long powerpoint boredom. Instead, you will get the chance to try the examples and demos yourself, you can even write your own first lines of code with the Wikitude SDK if you are keen. And of course we will give you a preview on our all new upcoming SDK version 5 slated for July 21st. We will also give you a demo of our 3D tracking capabilities, scheduled for public release in September. For those who might have been taken by surprise by Apple's acquisition of metaio, we will also help you compare products and find solutions.

Company

Wikitude GmbH is the world’s leading mobile augmented reality (AR) technology provider for smartphones, tablets and digital eyewear. Its fully in-house developed AR technology is available through the Wikitude AR SDK
enabling brands, agencies and developers to achieve their AR goals. With tens of thousands of developer accounts and thousands of published AR apps, Wikitude has grown to be the AR platform of choice. The company chairs the international AR standardization group as part of the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC). Wikitude® is a registered trademark of Wikitude GmbH, for more information please visit: www.wikitude.com

Speaker

Martin is the CTO of Wikitude and is managing the Wikitude development team. He is also chairing the Augmented Reality Markup Language (ARML) 2.0 Standards Working Group within the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC). ARML 2.0 has recently been published as an official OGC Standard for describing and interacting with AR scenes. Martin studied both Computer Science and Mathematics at the University of Salzburg, Austria and the Victoria University of Technology in Melbourne, Australia. He is holding a PhD in Applied Computer Sciences and an Master in Mathematics. Before joining Wikitude, he was working as a software engineer for Sony DADC.

Sponsor

Thanks to Wikitude and Anyline for the food and drinks

No video-recording or live stream planned at this time.

events.name: Free Augmented Reality Holographic Workshop using Unity3D & Vuforia
events.description:
Please come with Unity3D already installed on your laptop. Note that Unity3D requires 2GB of space.

Guys, 
I am currently working as a Developer Evangelist for Epson Moverio and my objective for this workshop is to show you how to create a very much simplified barebones version of the following Augmented Reality training application shown on this video. 

In other words, I want to show you how to create an application that projects a 3D holographic animation next to a paper marker and which progresses from scene to scene without requiring the user to use his hands.  Except in this case, we won't be using the animated model of an Air Conditioning unit, we'll be using some other random free 3D animated model we find on the Unity asset store. 

I'll have a pair of Epson Moverio BT-200 glasses with me (which is Android-based), but the Vuforia SDK I plan on introducing you to can also be tested on most Android devices, iOS devices, and also most importantly on your regular development laptop with its web cam. 

If you intend to test the application on an actual mobile device, please make sure either the relevant Android SDK or the relevant iOS SDK is also installed on your laptop (in addition to Unity3D). And don't forget to bring the usb cable that comes with your device. If you don't want to test on an actual mobile device, that's fine also, but just make sure that Unity3D is still installed on your laptop and that your laptop comes with a webcam. 

Optional

If you'd like to further prepare for this workshop, you can do so by registering with Vuforia, confirming your email address, and creating a free license key. When creating the license key, just pick Android, iOS, or digital eyeware depending on what device you bring with you (and if you have your own digital 3D AR glasses, bring them with you, it would be great to test the same application on it, and it would also be great to see how your glasses compare to the Moverio BT-200).

When downloading the Vuforia SDK, download the "Unity Vuforia SDK" (which is cross-platform on Android and iOS). This SDK is only 33.16 MB.  Double-clicking on it should bring up automatically Unity (assuming Unity3D is installed correctly). We won't be covering the native Android or iOS Vuforia SDKs, so there is no need to download those. There won't be any need to bring your own paper markers (unless you create your own custom one). I'll bring many paper copies of the Stones marker, which Vuforia uses by default for many of its samples. 

If you want to select your own free 3D animation before I select one for you during the workshop, you can select one by going to the Unity asset store and using its filter to filter for free assets (click on the little triangle next to filter a second time if it only gives you access to sorting). You can also get to the asset store directly from Unity by pressing Ctrl-9 (or Cmd-9 on a Mac).

Bio: 

Stephan Branczyk

Android mobile programming expert and Developer Evangelist for Epson-Moverio AR glasses. He has worked on the Android version of Eat24, a food delivery ordering application. Taught AndroidBootcamps. He co-organizes this group and several other technical meetups. You can follow him on Twitter @frenchaccent.

events.name: Google Cloud Bigtable
events.description:
Title: Google Cloud Bigtable: what is it for?

Abstract:

Bigtable is a sparsely populated table that can scale to billions of rows and thousands of columns, allowing you to store petabytes of data.

That sounds impressive, but what's Bigtable really great at? When should you use it instead of instead of Cloud SQL or Datastore?

In this talk Jen Tong, a Developer Advocate from Google, will explain why Bigtable is awesome and show you some demos that shows it shining.

Speaker bio:
Jenny is a Developer Advocate on Cloud at Google. In this role she helps developers build cool stuff on all sorts of platforms. If she's away from her laptop, she's probably skating around a roller derby track, or hanging from aerial silk.

We appreciate venue host Hurricane Electric for the use of the space.

Pizzas and drinks will be available thanks to Google!

events.name: Android Study Jam for Beginners
events.description:
When is it?

Five Saturdays  / Mar 19 - Apr 16  /  9am - Noon

What is it about?

Study Jams are community-organized study groups around Google online developer courses. The goal is to support as many students as possible in completing the course, thereby raising the technical level of the community. Our group will focus on the Udacity Android Fundamentals Study Jam and follow material for the course Android Development for Beginners. This course is free, please register using this link: https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

And who can/should participate:

The Study Jams for Android for Beginners is best suited for two audiences:

1) Those new to programming

2) Those with programming experience who have never used Android

The beginner level of the course allows for a broad appeal. Newbies, students, and experienced programmers new to Android can all benefit from this course.

What will you get out of it?

• Personal tutoring on the course material

• Community setting to support course learning

• Google-offered Study Jams completion certificate

• Discount on the Android Nanodegree upon course completion

• Opportunity to join Google Launchpad with completed app, pending app quality

Please eat breakfast beforehand, or bring snacks/coffee with you. We're not planning on having any food/snacks for this study jam.

events.name: Modern JavaScript Framework: Native Mobile App
events.description:
This is a cross-listing with the following event. Please do not double-subscribe

http://www.meetup.com/Silicon-Valley-Web-Builder/events/234262095/

////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

Fuse has developed a declarative and intuitive JS/Markup approach to native mobile app development. We've taken the quick, dynamic workflow that JavaScript provides, and coupled it with an advanced, native UI framework designed specifically for building beautiful mobile apps. All of this helps us to reduce iteration time between changes to an absolute minimum without sacrificing native performance, making app development faster, easier, and a heck of a lot more fun.

In this introductory workshop, we'll give a quick overview of the technology and demo exciting possibilities Fuse opens for our users such as instant, on-device update of code and markup, and specialized user interface primitives designed tosuccinctly describe data presentation and animation in a way you only dreamed of with HTML5. All along the way, we'll get live, hands-on experience working with these tools, on our devices, fully native, in real-time.

Presenters:

Three Fuse engineers from Norway
Andreas Kennedy Rønning
Kristian Hasselknippe
Morten Fornes (CTO)

events.name: VR Apps on Daydream Android
events.description:
This event is in cooperation with the Bay Area Android Developer Group.

This Wednesday night, Sept 20th, we'll have two talks related to developing VR apps for the Daydream platform on Android: 

1. Using the Unreal 4.0 game engine with the NDK/C++. 

by Tony Constantinides

 2. Developing using Java on the open source Samsung GearVRfframework 

by Bo Huang, Samsung 

+ giveaway of 5 free tickets to the San Francisco Oct 18-19, 2017 Samsung Developer Conference.  SDC2017 will be packed with technical talks, hands-on labs, thought leader panels, and more.

Giveaway will either be in the form of a GearVRf related quiz or a simple raffle, we haven't decided yet. Must be present to win.  

If you don't win, use this link for a time-limited 50% discount for our members to SDC2017. 

If we do the quiz, it will be with Kahoot, so you'll need to be present and have a phone or a computer with a web browser (and a working web connection, using either a mobile data connection or wifi).  One quiz entry per person please, using your first name and the first initial of your last name. If you don't use your real name during the quiz, it will be assumed that you do not want to be in the running for a free SDC ticket and that you're just doing the quiz for fun. 

If we do the quiz, a PIN to the quiz will be given out during the event itself. If you want to increase your chances of winning a free ticket, you should try setting up a working VR project using GearVRf on your computer by yourself before the talk and/or take copious notes during the presentation itself. 

Thanks to Google and Launchpad for the food and drinks. Subscribe here to receive biweekly event updates from Launchpad Space

Agenda:

6:30 Check-in, food, & Networking

6:55 Welcome message

7:00-7:40 Topic #1

~ 8:00-8:20 Topic #2 

8:40 Q&As, Announcements 

8:55 End

Developing VR apps/3D content with the NDK/C++

Want to lean AR/VR content creation? Want to create 3D games for Android? Do you want to generate 3D content for Android? Want to enhance your NDK skillet and take your C++ code on Android to the next Level? You need to lean how to leverage the Unreal 4.0 C++ game engine which allows you to do all this and more. I cover version 4.17 which has major bug fixes and enhancements for Android development as well as support for Daydream platform. I cover the key classes and how to do basic stuff like animation and Actor movement and how to manipulate textures in your app. 

Tony Constantinides is a Android Java/C++ engineer. 

Developing VR apps with Java

You don’t need to know Unity or Unreal to make VR applications. Samsung’s open source GearVRf Java framework empowers Java developers to get into the game. In this introductory talk, Bo will show you the many features it packs and how to get started.

https://gearvrf.org

Bo Huang works on Samsung’s games and VR team and has a background programming games for Mforma, Namco, Zynga, and engineering scientist on advanced rendering for X-rite. He is happy to help you on your VR journey 
https://bohuang3d.wordpress.com/ 
https://www.linkedin.com/in/bohuang3d/

Where:

Launchpad Space

Subscribe here ( https://goo.gl/forms/kllPDSpCSzuJOX7I2 ) to receive biweekly event updates from Launchpad Space

Thanks to Google and Launchpad for the food and drinks.

Hey Kaamel, get the conversation started!

Thomas Flynn

Tom Flynn is a director of software at Samsung Research America (SRA). In this role he is responsible for multiple Virtual Reality (VR) projects including the Gear VR Framework (GearVRf). Prior to joining Samsung, Tom was involved in many 3D graphics projects at companies like Panasonic, Sony Playstation (RSX debugger), Silicon Graphics (Performer, Inventor, OpenGL) and the Boeing Company at Kennedy Space Center.

Bala Thinagarajan

Bala Thinagarajan is a Solutions Architect at Samsung.  Bala has rich experience working on various telecom technologies including VOIP, OMA-DM/DS, FOTA, FEMTO and Enterprise Mobile Security. He is a Subject Matter Expert in the field of Enterprise Mobility Solutions.  In addition, he is a Knox and Customization evangelist at Samsung.

Daniel Molinero

Daniel is an Android Software Engineer at Groupon. He is a passionate Science geek with special interest in performance, design and security.
Before joining Groupon, he worked as a Web and Android developer for 6 years, participating in the development of some Android applications such as Hostelworld, Bonobu and now Groupon.
He is keen on contributing to the community by writing articles and collaborating on some open source projects: Toothpick, Dart & Henson, etc. Moreover, he has taken part in some conferences: Berlin and Boston Droidcon, Mobile Era, DroidKaigi or AndDevCon.

Siamak Ashrafi

Ash - CTO @ ZoeWave building physiologically intelligent clothing called ZoeWear.  Combining biotech, mobile and fashion to build clothing that keeps people healthy while looking great*.Zoe(“life”)Wear “wearable for life” is built on his experience in all three fields.

Erik Kamp :
Erik is an Android Software Engineer at Groupon with 4.5 years of experience building mobile applications. He is passionate about mobile development and improving the aesthetics and speed of applications to ensure the sleekest UI possible. Erik has architected and contributed to large scale Android applications used by millions of users on the PlayStore. He enjoys spending time creating tools for Android application profiling, learning new development languages and finding new ways to improve the usability of mobile applications.

Aolei Zhang :
Aolei is an Android Software Engineer at Groupon. She has been building her career there as a developer for 5 years since graduating from Carnegie Mellon with an MSc in 2013. Since then, he has worked as an Android developer at Groupon and now manages the Android Search & Discovery team. Besides working on the Android platform, Eric also enjoys writing games in C#/Unity.

https://kotlinlang.org/docs/reference/comparison-to-java.html
All the pros and almost non of the cons.

Kotlin fixes a series of issues that Java suffers from:

Null references are controlled by the type system.
No raw types
Arrays in Kotlin are invariant
Kotlin has proper function types, as opposed to Java's SAM-conversions
Use-site variance without wildcards
Kotlin does not have checked exceptions

What Kotlin has that Java does not
=================================
Lambda expressions + Inline functions = performant custom control structures
Extension functions
Null-safety
Smart casts
String templates
Properties
Primary constructors
First-class delegation
Type inference for variable and property types
Singletons
Declaration-site variance & Type projections
Range expressions
Operator overloading
Companion objects
Data classes
Separate interfaces for read-only and mutable collections
Coroutines
